h i g h l i g h t s
Aqueous nano-emulsion of cerium oxide improved combustion quality. Impacts of low-level water containing cerium oxide in B5 on engine performance and characteristics were first investigated. bsfc of B5W3m was 5% and 16% lower than those of neat B5 and neat B5W3, respectively. B5W3m increased bte by over 23 and 11% compared with B5W3 and B5, respectively. B5W3m considerably reduced CO, HC, and NOx emissions by 51, 45, and 27% compared with B5W3, respectively.

a b s t r a c t
Improving fuel combustion in engines and consequently reducing environmentally-unfavorable emissions is of prominent importance in addressing some of the main challenges of the current century, i.e., global warming and climate change. Fuel additives are considered as efficient way for improving fuel properties and to diminish engine emissions. In line with this, the present research was focused on the simultaneous application of water (3, 5, and 7 wt.%) and cerium oxide nano particles (90 ppm) as metal-based additive into biodiesel/diesel fuel blend (B5) and their impacts on the performance and emission characteristics of a single cylinder four stroke diesel engine were investigated. The findings revealed that the aqueous nano-emulsion of cerium oxide improved the overall combustion quality. More specifically, the brake specific fuel consumption (bsfc) of B5 containing 3% water and 90 ppm cerium oxide (B5W3m) was measured 5% and 16% lower than those of neat B5 and neat B5 containing 3% water (B5W3), respectively. Moreover, the B5W3m fuel blend increased brake thermal efficiency (bte) by over 23 and 11% compared with B5W3 and B5, respectively. B5W3m also considerably reduced CO, HC, and NOx emissions by 51, 45, and 27% compared with B5W3. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report exploring the impacts of low-level water containing cerium oxide in B5 on engine performance and emission characteristics.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
One of the major challenges faced by the transportation sector is to meet the increasingly stringent exhaust gas emission standards set to protect the environment and to reverse the
ends to .1016/j.
unfavorable impacts of this sector on climate change. In fact, global transportation is responsible for more than 25% of the total greenhouse gases (GHGs) emissions. Improvements in engine technologies as well as exploring less polluting energy carriers have been among the main solutions constantly considered to overcome these challenges [1,2]. Biodiesel is the most extended alternative for diesel fuel offering unique advantages such as biodegradability and non-toxicity, inherent lubricity, low emission characteristics, as well as similar properties to those of mineral diesel fuel [3,4].
Biodiesel could be produced from various vegetable oils and animal fat feedstock [5]. However, waste oriented resources such as waste cooking oil (WCO) are more favorable from both economic and food security point of views [6,7]. The most commonly-practiced method for biodiesel production is alkalicatalyzed transesterification [8,9]. Transesterification is in fact an alcoholysis process (using methanol or ethanol) taking place in the presence of a basic catalyst (commonly NaOH or KOH) and through which triglycerides are converted into fatty acid methyl/ ethyl esters [10–12].
Numerous studies exist on the exhaust emissions of neat biodiesel as well as various biodiesel/diesel blends when combusted in diesel engines [13–15]. Generally, these studies claim that the combustion of biodiesel and its blend led to decreases in unburned hydrocarbons (HC), carbon monoxide (CO), and particulate matter (PM) emissions while unfavorable increases in nitrogen oxides (NOx) were also observed compared with pure diesel fuel [4,16,17]. A large variety of fuel additives have been put to test over the last decades aiming to further decrease exhaust emissions caused by biodiesel-diesel blends and in particular to overcome the general deterioration in NOx emissions caused by biodiesel inclusion [8,9,18–21].
Among various fuel additives investigated, water addition has attracted a great deal of attention due to its remarkable impacts on diminishing NOx emissions [22]. Three strategies have been introduced for using water in internal combustion engine including water-diesel (or biodiesel-diesel) emulsion (WDE), inlet manifold water injection (or fumigation) and direct water injection into the cylinder [23,24]. Amongst these strategies, WDE is of more interest owing to this fact that its application not only could effectively diminish hazardous gaseous emissions but also requires no engine modifications [25–27]. More specifically, it has been well documented that the combustion of WDE fuels can efficiently reduce NOx and PM emissions simultaneously without causing significant increases in brake specific fuel consumption (bsfc) [25,28,29]. However, WDE combustion could reportedly increase the amount of HC emissions as a result of in-cylinder temperature reduction caused by high latent heat of vaporization of water [30]. In a study, Yang et al. investigated the performance and emission characteristics of a four cylinder turbocharged diesel engine and reported that the addition of 15% water into diesel fuel at full load and 3200 rpm engine speed reduced the exhausted NOx emissions by 30% while negligible increases in bsfc were observed [27].
Contrary to the above-mentioned studies, Liang et al. claimed that bsfc was increased by 12% when a diesel fuel emulsion containing 30% (v/v) water was used [31]. Similar findings were reported by Koc and Abdullah who studied water inclusion into biodiesel and found that 15% water in biodiesel increased bsfc by 7.2% at 2800 rpm. They also attributed increased CO emission and reduced NOx emission to the presence of water in the fuel blend [32].
Another group of diesel fuel additives increasingly used as combustion improver in diesel engines is metal-based additives [33–35]. The metals contained in the structure of these additives include manganese, iron, copper, barium, cerium, calcium, and platinum which offer catalytic activities during the combustion process. Metal-based additives could reportedly increase
Please cite this article in press as: Khalife E et al. A novel emulsion fuel cont improve diesel engines performance and reduce exhaust emissions: Par fuel.2017.06.033
combustion quality simultaneously leading to reduced diesel fuel emissions and bsfc. In the year 2008, Kao et al. studied a diesel fuel containing nano aluminum and claimed higher heat release and lower NOx emission compared with neat diesel fuel [36]. In a more recent study, Venkatesan and Kadiresh investigated on the addition of 50 ml cerium oxide into diesel and biodiesel/diesel blend fuels and reported that bte and bsfc were improved while HC and NOx emissions were reduced compared with neat diesel fuel [37].
As mentioned earlier, using water in fuel blends could potentially result in increases in fuel consumption and some of emissions, e.g., CO. Therefore, in order to take advantage of the NOx reducing feature of WDE fuels, the combination of metallic-based additive with WDE has been put forth as an effective strategy to simultaneously overcome the disadvantages of using water in diesel engines and to covering its benefits [30]. For instance, Farfaletti et al. in the 2005 explored the effects of cerium oxide addition into a WDE fuel containing 20% water (v/v) and reported that in comparison with the WDE without metal-based additive, the new emulsion fuel could simultaneously reduce PM, CO, and HC [38]. Keskin et al. also argued that metal-based additives when reacting with water could result in the production of hydroxyl radicals which in turn led to lower soot oxidation temperature [39]. Recently, Vellaiyan and Amirthagadeswaran studied on the addition of 50 and 100 ppm zinc into diesel fuel containing 10% water, and reported reductions in HC, CO, and NOx emissions [40].
As mentioned above and to the best of our knowledge, the studies conducted on the combined application of water and metalbased additives in diesel fuel are only limited to high water addition levels, i.e., >5%. Moreover, little information is available on the impact of nano cerium oxide addition into water-biodieseldiesel emulsion (WBDE) blends on engine performance and emissions characteristics. Therefore, the present study was set to investigate the engine performance and emissions features of aqueous nano cerium oxide (90 ppm) addition into B5 containing lowlevel water (3, 5, and 7% wt.) using a single cylinder diesel engine.

sections.heading: 2.1. Biodiesel production
sections.text: Biodiesel production was carried out by transesterification of pre-treated WCO with methanol and in the presence of potassium hydroxide (KOH) as catalyst in a stirred tank reactor at 60 C for 1 h. After the reaction was completed, the mixture was allowed to settle for 1 h in order to separate methanol–biodiesel fractions by gravity. The acid value of the bottom layer was then measured and if it was at above 0.5 mg KOH/g, the pretreatment step was repeated before the transesterification reaction. The resultant biodiesel was washed three times. Water consumption throughout the washing and purification steps to remove residuals was minimized by following the method described by Jaber et al. [41]. Some of the properties of the produced WCO biodiesel were bioprospected based on the fatty acid composition profile of the oil by using ‘‘Biodiesel Analyzer Ver. 1.1” (available on ‘‘http:// www.brteam.ir/biodieselanalyzer”) [42].

sections.heading: 2.2. Fuel samples preparation
sections.text:
Three different levels of water (i.e., 3, 5, 7% wt.) with and without 90 ppm cerium oxide were emulsified in 1 L of B5 (labeled as B5W3, B5W5, B5W7, B5W3m, B5W5m, and B5W7m, respectively). Emulsification of water and cerium oxide in B5 was achieved by including 75 ml of a 1:2 blend of two known surfactants of Tween 80 and Span 80 (Merk, Germany) into B5 prior to the addition of
aining aqueous nano cerium oxide additive in diesel–biodiesel blends to t I – Experimental analysis. Fuel (2017), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.
water and/or the metal-based catalyst. Finally, the prepared emulsions were stabilized by using a Polytron homogenizer (Switzerland) at room temperature for 15 min. Engine experiments were run with different WBDE fuel blends with and without cerium oxide (WBDEm and WBDE, respectively). Neat B5 and diesel samples were also considered as controls.

sections.heading: 2.3. Engine set-up
sections.text: The experiments were conducted on a 0.507 L single-cylinder, four-stroke, water cooled, direct injection and variable compression ratio (VCR) (Max. CR 22) Ricardo E6 diesel engine. Moreover, the engine was an air-cooled, natural aspirate direct injection and the start of injection was at 38 before top dead center. The engine displacement was 507 cc, and was loaded by a 22 kW electrical dynamometer. The in-cylinder pressure sensor was a piezoelectric transducer (QC43D, AVL). A charge amplifier was used for the pressure sensor and for analyzing the combustion pressure while the location of relevant crank angle was investigated by a computer program with a 0.1 CAD resolution. Crank angle position was measured using a magnetic rotary encoder (MES-2500D-T, Fotek), installed on the engine crankshaft with a resolution of 2500 pulses per revolution. Engine specifications are tabulated in Table 1 and the engine setup and the instrumentations used are illustrated in Fig. 1. Engine test was performed at a constant speed (1000 rpm) and four different loads (i.e., 25, 50, 75, and 100%). An AVL-735 fuel mass flow meter was employed for measuring fuel consumption and Air Fuel Ratio (AFR) was calculated by a Lambda sensor. An AVL gas analyzer was employed to measure CO, HC, and CO2 using infrared measurement. Oxygen (O2) and NOx measurements were recorded using the electrochemical method. The measurement accuracies and the resolution of the gas analyzer are presented in Table 2.

sections.heading: 2.4. Engine performance and combustion characteristics
sections.text: Main engine performance specifications, i.e., brake power (bp), brake specific fuel consumption (bsfc) and brake thermal efficiency (bte) were recorded at the different loads investigated.

sections.heading: 3.1. Fuel properties
sections.text:
Biodiesel properties were either estimated by using ‘‘Biodiesel Analyzer Ver. 2.2” software based on the fatty acid composition of the WCO (Table 3) or measured based on the American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) (Table 4), showing a good agreement with the standard values. Moreover, as shown in Table 5, calorific value was increasingly decreased in response to elevating concentrations of water in B5 fuel while the viscosity value of emulsified fuel blends showed an opposite trend. sections.heading: 3.2. Engine performance
sections.text: The engine performance characteristics of the WBDE fuels with and without cerium oxide nano particles (i.e., brake power, torque, bsfc, and bte) and emissions (CO, O2, CO2, HC, and NOx) in an unmodified diesel engine were investigated and the results obtained in comparison with the those of B5 and neat diesel fuel as controls are presented and discussed herein.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Engine brake power
sections.text:
Brake power (bp) was slightly decreased for B5 compared with neat diesel fuel (Fig. 2a). This was in line with the findings of the previously-published reports [44–47]. For instance, Liaquat et al. also reported lower bp for different biodiesel/diesel fuel blends compared with neat diesel [47]. They argued that the reduction in bp could be attributed to the lower heating value of biodiesel than diesel [47]. Addition of water into B5 at all inclusion rates investigated led to further decreases in bp values of the WBDE fuel blends obviously due to the lower heating values of the resultant blends caused by the presence of water (Table 5). Decreases in bp values in response to water inclusion into biodiesel-diesel fuel blends have been also reported by Abdullah and Koc [48], also highlighting lower heating values of the water-containing fuel blends as the cause.
On the contrary, the inclusion of cerium oxide nano particle in WBDE (i.e., WBDEm) resulted in higher bp values compared with their WBDE counterparts. For instance, the addition of 90 ppm cerium oxide into B5W3 improved the bp of the fuel blend to values comparable with that of B5. This finding could be attributed to the fact that metal-based additives could react with water at higher temperatures during the combustion process which could in turn result in hydrogen generation and consequently, could promote the combustion process in the engine cylinder [36,49]. Moreover, the bp showed an increasing trend in reponse to the addition of cerium oxide into the B5W5 while on the contrary, it decreased when cerium oxide was added into B5W7. This could be due to an increased cooling impact when further water was included (7%) into the emulsion which must have reduced the positive impact originally exerted through the micro-explosion phenomenon caused by the encapsulated water in the emulsion fuel.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Brake specific fuel consumption (bsfc)
sections.text:
bsfc is defined as the ratio of the fuel consumed to the engine power produced at a given time. Although, there are several studies conducted to evaluate metal-based nano particle addition into biodiesel-diesel fuel blends [50–52], however, to the best of our knowledge, there are no published reports on the impact of lowlevel water containing cerium oxide inclusion in biodiesel-diesel blends on fuel consumption as discussed herein. Fig. 2b presents the bsfc results measured at different engine loads. Accordingly, the bsfc value increased as a result of the inclusion of biodiesel in diesel due to lower calorific value of biodiesel [53,54]. Water inclusion into B5 also led to increased bsfc values compared with B5 and neat diesel and these increments were proportional with the amount of water added. This was obviously ascribed to the deterioration of calorific values of the emulsified fuel blends caused by the presence of water [28,31,55]. Moreover, these findings could also be attributed to the increasing impact of water on the viscosity of emulsified fuel blends (Table 5).

On the contrary, by inclusion of cerium oxide into B5 containing water, bsfc values were remarkably improved. For instance, the bsfc of B5W3m was 5% and 16% lower than those of neat B5 and neat B5W3, respectively. From the mechanism point of view,
Please cite this article in press as: Khalife E et al. A novel emulsion fuel cont improve diesel engines performance and reduce exhaust emissions: Par fuel.2017.06.033
metal-based additives are generally decomposed before the vaporization of fuel and water, releasing active metal atoms (cerium in the present study) which could consequently reduce the formation of unburned carbon deposits on cylinder walls [30]. This phenomenon could in turn lead to a friction reduction between the engine parts, i.e., the piston and the cylinder resulting in reduced bsfc [56,57].
Sajith et al. conducted a study to investigate on the effect of different cerium oxide inclusion rates into neat biodiesel and also claimed decreased bsfc [58]. In another study, Mirzajanzadeh et al. studied the combustion characteristics of different
aining aqueous nano cerium oxide additive in diesel–biodiesel blends to t I – Experimental analysis. Fuel (2017), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.
combination of cerium oxide with carbon nanotubes added into B5 and reported that bsfc was reduced by 4.5% [9]. Rao and Anand combusted neat biodiesel containing 5 and 10% water and three different concentrations of aluminum nano particles (i.e., 25, 50, and 100 ppm) and argued that the inclusion of aluminum nano particles into Biodiesel-diesel blends containing water resulted in lower bsfc [21].

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Brake thermal efficiency (bte)
sections.text:
The heat equivalent of brake power to heat equivalent of the fuel consumed is defined as brake thermal efficiency [59]. Fig. 2c shows the bte values of the fuel blends investigated. As presented, the combustion of B5 led to a lower bte value compared with neat diesel which is related to the lower calorific value and higher bsfc value of biodiesel as shown in Table 5 and Fig. 2 [60].
The addition of water into B5 deteriorated the bte values while the addition of cerium oxide compensated for the unfavorable impacts of water. In case of the emulsified fuel blend containing

90 ppm cerium oxide (B5W3m), bte was measured higher than neat B5 and B5W3. More specifically, the combustion of B5W3m increased bte on average by up to 23 and 11% compared with B5W3 and neat B5, respectively. This bte improvement in response to the presence of the metal-based additive in the emulsified fuel blend could be explained by the slightly higher peak cylinder pressure and faster heat release rate as previously elaborated by [37,61]. In fact, due to the relation between bte and bsfc, the positive impact of cerium oxide on increasing bte could be attributed to the lower friction between the engine parts. The chemical reaction between cerium oxide and carbons during the high temperature of the combustion process could have effectively prevented the formation of carbon deposits on the cylinder wall [9].
The findings of the present study were in agreement with those previously reports on the application of metal-based additives in biodiesel-diesel blends. For instance, Venkatesan and Kadiresh also studied the impact of 50 ml/L aqueous cerium oxide inclusion on the combustion characteristics of B15 and neat diesel and claimed improved bte vales [37]. In a more recent investigation, Arockiasamy and Anand explored the addition of 30 ppm cerium oxide into B30 and their results revealed that cerium oxide increased the bte value of B30 to the value observed for neat diesel [62].

Generally, at high loads which are characterized by richer fuel/air ratios, the existing carbon contained in the injected fuel is not exposed to adequate oxygen in order to be oxidized into CO2. On the other hand, leaner fuel/air ratios could lead to decreased cylinder temperatures which could in turn prevent the complete conversion of CO into CO2. Therefore, insufficient oxygen and low cylinder temperature during the combustion process are two the main reasons leading to high CO emissions. The results of the current study revealed that the combustion of B5 at high loads led to reduced CO emissions (Fig. 3). Moreover, at the highest load inves-
Please cite this article in press as: Khalife E et al. A novel emulsion fuel cont improve diesel engines performance and reduce exhaust emissions: Par fuel.2017.06.033
tigated, i.e., 100%, CO emission stood at 66 and 71 g/kW.h for B5 and dieselو respectively. This was probably due to the oxygen content of biodiesel particularly in the rich combustion zones which in turn resulted in improved combustion quality.
The addition of water into B5 generally increased the CO emission (Fig. 3). This could be ascribed to the impact of water on
aining aqueous nano cerium oxide additive in diesel–biodiesel blends to t I – Experimental analysis. Fuel (2017), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.
reducing cylinder temperature and therefore, the highest water addition level practiced, i.e., 7% led to the highest CO emission. Similar observations were previously made by other researchers who also reported the combustion of WDE fuels [48,64,65].
In the present study, cerium oxide inclusion into the WBDE decreased CO emission compared with cerium oxide-free WBDE (Fig. 3). This could be possibly attributed to the dominant premixed lean combustion [66]. Moreover, improvements in bsfc efficiency have positive impacts on CO emission as well [56]. The most favorable result for emulsion fuels containing water and cerium oxide was observed when B5W3m was combusted showing up to 30% reduction in CO emission at 100% load compared with B5W3. Similar reductions in CO emission were previously reported by other researchers such as Selvan et al., Kannan et al., and Mehta et al. who studied on the addition of cerium oxide, iron, and aluminum in ethanol-biodiesel-diesel, biodiesel, and neat diesel, respectively [35,67,68]. Basha and Anand also investigated on the aluminum nano particles inclusion into WDE in several studies and claimed that water addition resulted in increased CO emissions compared with neat diesel while the inclusion of the metal-based additive in the WDE could efficiently compensate for the unfavorable effects of water [29,69,70].

sections.heading: 3.3.2. CO2 emission
sections.text:
Fig. 4 displays the CO2 emissions through the combustion of the studied fuel blends. The results obtained indicated that B5 combustion led to slightly more CO2 emission compared with neat diesel which could be ascribed to the lower heating value of biodiesel compared with neat diesel. The presence of water at all the levels practiced (WBDE fuels) caused increases in CO2 emissions compared with neat B5, which was proportional with the water concentration in the fuel blend. Similar findings, i.e., increased CO2 emission in response to water addition into fuel blends, were also reported by previous studies [71–73]. For instance, Al-Sabagh et al. investigated on high water concentrations in WDE and reported higher CO2 emission [72]. Alahmer et al. attributed these increases in CO2 emission in the presence of water to increased oxygen content in the mixture or in another word the leaner nature of the mixture [73].
By adding 90 ppm cerium oxide into WBDE, CO2 emission was decreased compared with catalyst-free WBDE (Fig. 4). Moreover, lower CO2 emissions were recorded for B5W3m emulsion than B5. This could be explained by the impact of the metal-based additive as catalyst and the consequent combustion improvements [35].

sections.heading: 3.3.3. O2 emission
sections.text:
The amount of emitted O2 in the exhaust gases reflects the value of air to fuel ratio (lambda value) in an engine. In better words, the amount of O2 in the exhaust gases will be naturally decreased at a lower lambda value. When an engine works at a constant Lambda value, if extra oxygen is measured in the exhaust gases, it is an indication of low quality of combustion or in another words, showing that the oxygen present did not effectively contribute to the combustion process. As presented in Fig. 5, by increasing the engine load, O2 emission in the exhaust gas also decreased. Moreover, water inclusion into B5 led to higher O2 emissions compared with B5 and neat diesel which could be attributed to the leaner consumed fuel (due to the addition of water) during the combustion (Fig. 5).
Inclusion of the metal-based additive to the WBDE fuels improved the combustion probably as a result the high reactivity of metal-based as catalyst leading to lowered emitted oxygen amount. [74]. Among the different biodiesel blends tested, the combustion of B5W3m was associated with the most favorable
Please cite this article in press as: Khalife E et al. A novel emulsion fuel cont improve diesel engines performance and reduce exhaust emissions: Par fuel.2017.06.033
emitted oxygen content, which was on average by 8% lower than B5, the second most favorable biodiesel blend.

sections.heading: 3.3.4. HC emission
sections.text:
HC emission is considered by many as the main indication of incomplete combustion. Fig. 6 shows the variations in HC emission of the investigated fuel blends. The findings of present study revealed that the combustion of B5 led to decreased HC emission at low engine loads while increased HC emission at high engine loads compared with neat diesel fuel. This reflected that B5 was not effectively combusted at high loads vs. lower loads, owing to the high local fuel to air ratio at high loads causing increases in HC emissions [75]. Moreover, the HC emissions of the WBDE fuels increased by increasing the amount of water added into the emulsion fuels. In the case of B5W3, the differences in HC emissions compared with those of B5 were negligible except at 100% load (Fig. 6). This finding was in line with those of the previous studies which have stressed on the negative impacts of water addition into biodiesel/diesel fuel blend on HC emissions as a result of reducing effect of water on cylinder temperature during combustion [76–78]. In fact, based on the findings of present study, the positive impacts of water addition into biodiesel/diesel fuel blend on HC emissions could only be observed at the lowest level of water addition practiced (i.e., 3%). This could be explained by the occurrence of the micro-explosion phenomenon leading to more effective mixing of the injected fuel with air (Fig. 7) [79]. More specifically, micro explosion phenomenon takes place when the encapsulated water in the injected fuel due to its higher heat of vaporization, instantaneously vaporizes prior to the diesel fuel (or biodiesel/diesel blend fuel). Therefore, the large fuel droplets divide into smaller droplets leading to a consequent better exposure of fuel to air.
Addition of cerium oxide nano particles into B5 containing different levels of water led to apparant HC emission reductions (Fig. 6). The most favorable results on HC emissions reduction among all the biodiesel-diesel blends investigated was achieved when B5W3m, i.e., by up to 20% and 45% compared with B5 and B5W3, respectively. Such decreases could be attributed to the catalytic activity of the metal-based additive during the combustion process [80,81]. Similar results were also reported by Ganesh and Gowrishankar who studied on the addition of two different metal-based additives (i.e., Magnalium (Al-Mg) and cobalt oxide (Co3O4)) into neat biodiesel and found considerable decreases in HC emissions [82]. Selvan et al. also reported HC emission reductions by using cerium oxide in diesel-biodiesel-ethanol blends [67]. In a series of investigations, Basha and Anand explored the combined effects of water and aluminum nano particle on the combustion characteristics of neat biodiesel and neat diesel [29,69,70]. They claimed that although water in both neat diesel and neat biodiesel had negative impacts on the emitted HC but the application of metal-based additives in both fuels could reduce their HC emissions to the values recorded for neat diesel and neat biodiesel.

sections.heading: 3.3.5. Nox emission
sections.text:
Principally reducing NOx emission is the main objective of adding water as additive into biodiesel/diesel fuel blends. This is ascribed to the fact that high temperatures during combustion is the key parameter leading to NOx emissions, and water could effectively exert a cooling effect and consequently decrease NOx emission [64,73,83–86]. Fig. 7: Schematic presentation of the effect water inclusion on the combustion quality of WDE fuel through the occurrence of the micro-explosion phenomenon.
Fig. 8 displays the variations recorded in NOx emissions for the fuel blends tested. As presented, the combustion of B5W3 led to lower NOx emission compared with B5. In fact, the maximum NOx emission reduction of 11% was achieved when B5W3 emulsi-
aining aqueous nano cerium oxide additive in diesel–biodiesel blends to t I – Experimental analysis. Fuel (2017), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.
fied fuel was combusted. A number of researchers have also reported similar results [75,87,88]. For instance, Ithnin et al. investigated on the combustion of WDE and reported a high NOx emission reduction [22]. Also, Koc and Abdullah investigated on the water-biodiesel-diesel emulsion and found 8% NOx emission reduction [32].
On the contrary, NOx emission was increased by further increasing the water level in B5. More specifically, NOx emission was increased in case of B5W7 (at 50% load) by 36 and 38% compared with B5 and neat diesel, respectively. This could be probably ascribed to the fact that by increasing water content, more fuel would be needed in order to generate the same amount of power per hour (kW.h) leading to higher NOx emission. The addition of cerium oxide nano particles into the fuel blends resulted in reductions in NOx emissions compared with catalyst-free WBDE fuels (Fig. 8). It should be highlighted that although the reduction achieved in NOx emission was not considerable for B5W3m compared with B5W3 but it was by up to 28% compared with B5 at 100% load. Overall, the most favorable NOx emission reduction was observed during the combustion of B5W5m, by 22, 44, and 36% compared with neat B5W5, B5, and neat diesel, respectively. These improvements could be attributed to the catalyzing impact of the metal-based additive which consequently increased the cylinder temperature (Fig. 9) and power per hour leading to less fuel consumption for a constant power (Fig. 2). Another possible justification to the NOx emission reduction could be the increasing impact of metal-based additive on cetane number which could have consequently increased the combustion quality leading to NOx emission reduction [89–92]. Reduction in NOx emission in response to the addition of aluminum nano particles into WDE [29,69,70], magnalium (Al-Mg) and cobalt oxide (Co3O4) into neat biodiesel [82], and ferric chloride into neat biodiesel and neat diesel [35] have been previously reported as well.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
An experimental study on the application of WBDE (3, 5, and 7 wt.% water) using a single cylinder diesel engine, with neat diesel and B5 as controls, was conducted and based on the results abtained the following conclusions could be drawn:
bsfc was improved by the addition of cerium oxide nano particles into the WBDE fuels, especially in case of the B5W3 which led to a lower bsfc in comparison with B5. The addition of cerium oxide nano particles in the WBDE fuel improved engine bte. More specifically, higher bte was achieved during the combustion of B5W3m compared with neat B5W3 and B5.
Please cite this article in press as: Khalife E et al. A novel emulsion fuel cont improve diesel engines performance and reduce exhaust emissions: Par fuel.2017.06.033
CO emission was increased for the WBDE fuels but the inclusion of the cerium oxide nano particles led to favorable impacts on this emission with the best result obtained through the combustion of B5W3m (i.e., lower CO emission than those of catalyst-free B5W3 and B5). The most remarkable HC emission reduction was achieved during the combustion of B5W3m, i.e., by up to 20% and 45% compared with B5 and B5W3, respectively. The metal-based additive used reduced NOx emission and the most favorable result were observed during the combustion of B5W5m, i.e., by 22, 44, and 36% compared with neat B5W5, B5, and neat diesel, respectively.

metadata.abstractText: Improving fuel combustion in engines and consequently reducing environmentally-unfavorable emissions is of prominent importance in addressing some of the main challenges of the current century, i.e., global warming and climate change. Fuel additives are considered as efficient way for improving fuel properties and to diminish engine emissions. In line with this, the present research was focused on the simultaneous application of water (3, 5, and 7 wt.%) and cerium oxide nano particles (90 ppm) as metal-based additive into biodiesel/diesel fuel blend (B5) and their impacts on the performance and emission characteristics of a single cylinder four stroke diesel engine were investigated. The findings revealed that the aqueous nano-emulsion of cerium oxide improved the overall combustion quality. More specifically, the brake specific fuel consumption (bsfc) of B5 containing 3% water and 90 ppm cerium oxide (B5W3m) was measured 5% and 16% lower than those of neat B5 and neat B5 containing 3% water (B5W3), respectively. Moreover, the B5W3m fuel blend increased brake thermal efficiency (bte) by over 23 and 11% compared with B5W3 and B5, respectively. B5W3m also considerably reduced CO, HC, and NOx emissions by 51, 45, and 27% compared with B5W3. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report exploring the impacts of low-level water containing cerium oxide in B5 on engine performance and emission characteristics. 2017 Elsevier Ltd.
